How fast and how much you pop that top has more to do with it than any of the tapping methods you are trying. If you open that top with less gusto, it wouldn't overflow so badly. When the pressure is taken away that quickly, it causes the reaction to happen more noticeably. Don't pull the tab all the way up so quick and don't pop the top so much all at one time and you won't lose as much. Barely break the seal on the top, and I mean barely break the seal, then hold your thumb over it to keep the pressure from dropping so quickly. You'll still get sticky, though.

I use soft drinks in plastic bottles, because controlling how fast you let the pressure equalize works even better on bottled soft drinks. I do tap them still, though, to see if taking the cap off is going to cause it to still foam up, but that is only after slowly opening then closing the bottle a few times. It rarely takes more than 5 or 10 seconds that way and you don't lose any drink or make a mess.

I never understood why people think tapping the can would help a shaken soda can settle. The whole problem is the agitation causes the CO2 to separate from the water which pressurizes the can, and tapping is just going to agitate it more (if possibly only negligibly more). What you need to do is to get the CO2 to redissolve into the water, which is why waiting 30 seconds worked the best for them. You can also put the drink in the fridge/freezer, as cold water dissolves CO2 much more readily than warm water so the CO2 will redissolve faster and more reliably. (This is why warm drinks are the most explosive as the water can't dissolve as much of the CO2 and it separates much more easily.)

Alternatively, you could also open the can slowly so the pressure gets gradually released rather than all at once. It's harder to do with a can, but with a plastic bottle it's pretty straightforward.

In order to guess what is going to happen you need to know why it will happen.
When you open a can and it fizzes over it is all the pressure getting equalized with the atmosphere making all the gas bubbles expand because of the pressurized gasses in the bubbles. So if the bubbles are on the side of the can and you flick it enough to knock them off and leave it for a second in theory all the bubbles that made it to the top from the sides should pop thus resulting in less fizz. Where as tapping the top and/ or bottom will have less of an effect due to the way the can will ripple. In conclusion I believe that yes tapping the side will have some effect but not too sure if it Is a useful amount of an effect.

Paint shaker has very short stroke or distance of motion, while when shaking with hands the can travels longer distance.
When in paint shaker (short travel distance and high speed), bubbles cancel each other as if tapped to cancel bubbles.
But when shaken with hand (especially once) bubbles are agitated and pressure is built, thus more foamy.


If you want to make another experiment but with a long single stroke yet powerful, it would make your results more humanly accurate. :)

The tap methods all depend on the type of sweetener/sugar in the soda (If any), and the type of container (Plastic bottle, glass bottle, and can). For example, the bubbles created by a cane sugar drink will stick better to the sides of a plastic bottle than a can, because the plastic has more nucleation points than the can does, and sodas using a sweetener like Aspartame won't work in most cases because the bubbles they make are resistant to floating to the top when vibrated.

so to explain some of the chemistry behind it (keep in mind i am by no means an expert and you can gladly correct me at any time):


Within the Can there is a balance between the CO2 in the air that is present in the can and the acid that is mixed in the drink. Most times nearly all of it is mixed in the Drink so you have a nice fuzzy drink. Shaking it however agitates the CO2 in the drink so it forms actual CO2 wich mixes with the air. Because you can dissolve much more CO2 in the liquid, there is a pressure built up, wich in turn creates your "exploding cans".
The Paint shaker could actually shake it so much tho, that the liquid kind of dissolves the CO2 right as it forms, so its not as violent as you might think. A Single Shake could however create a small low pressure point in wich the gases are very likely to pop into, as there is more space they can occupy and therefore create a really high pressure wich dissolves rather quickly. Its the same reason a beer foams so violently when you give it a hit with another bottle from the top.
Now to the tapping: the only thing that the tapping really does is just removing some of the bubbles wich could grab liquid when the can is opened. These bubbles need time to form however. Just take a glass of coke for example you will only see tiny bubbles at first and 10 minutes later they are much larger although only very few of them still exist in your glass. So Tapping after shaking it so violently is basicly doing nothing. As more or less evident through your video.


Quick Sidenote: English is not my first language but i hope you learned something anyways.
